messages.text: Why am I getting warnings there?

elements.text: Why am I getting warnings there?

messages.text: So in my Manifest.toml there is `Missings` 0.4.5 listed, but there is no cache file for that on my system.

elements.text: So in my Manifest.toml there is
Missings
0.4.5 listed, but there is no cache file for that on my system.

messages.text: There are cache files for older versions.

elements.text: There are cache files for older versions.

messages.text: And as far as I can tell, SymbolServer is _not_ trying to cache that package either.

elements.text: And as far as I can tell, SymbolServer is
not
trying to cache that package either.

messages.text: So I think we still have some sort of bug there...

elements.text: So I think we still have some sort of bug there...

messages.text: I'll investigate, but if someone else has an idea, ping me!

elements.text: I'll investigate, but if someone else has an idea, ping me!

messages.text: So I think our general approach in the SymbolServer there is a bit incorrect :slightly_smiling_face: I think we are essentially looking at the top-level packages in the project, and if we have a cache file for these, we don't do anything. But what we really should do is look at all the packages in the manifest, and check whether there are cache files for all of those.

elements.text: So I think our general approach in the SymbolServer there is a bit incorrect

I think we are essentially looking at the top-level packages in the project, and if we have a cache file for these, we don't do anything. But what we really should do is look at all the packages in the manifest, and check whether there are cache files for all of those.

messages.text: I think also that the current approach where we essentially crawl through the hierarchy of packages could be greatly simplified by doing the following: just for the symbolserver process, we create a temporary env where we a) copy the Manifest.toml from the original env over, and then create a new `Project.toml` where we simply make every package in the `Manifest.toml` a top level package. We can then do the whole caching story completely flat: we just check whether we have a cache file for each package, and we can also just `import` every single package as a top level package directly in order to index things.

elements.text: I think also that the current approach where we essentially crawl through the hierarchy of packages could be greatly simplified by doing the following: just for the symbolserver process, we create a temporary env where we a) copy the Manifest.toml from the original env over, and then create a new
Project.toml
where we simply make every package in the
Manifest.toml
a top level package. We can then do the whole caching story completely flat: we just check whether we have a cache file for each package, and we can also just
import
every single package as a top level package directly in order to index things.

messages.text: What is not clear to me right now whether the current situation is a regression, or whether this has been like that for a while. And importantly: should we ship 1.1 with this not fixed for now? And fix it in a patch release? I would say "yes" because this doesn't crash anything.

elements.text: What is not clear to me right now whether the current situation is a regression, or whether this has been like that for a while. And importantly: should we ship 1.1 with this not fixed for now? And fix it in a patch release? I would say "yes" because this doesn't crash anything.

messages.text: Yeah that's a correct analysis of the caching issue and this is also not a regression. Your suggestion seems good - we should ship 1.1 without this change

elements.text: Yeah that's a correct analysis of the caching issue and this is also not a regression. Your suggestion seems good - we should ship 1.1 without this change

messages.text: Ok, I wrote the release announcement, here it is: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-vs-code-extension-1-1-released/54896>

attachments.title: [ANN] VS Code extension 1.1 released
attachments.text: We just released version 1.1 of the Julia extension for VS Code to the marketplace. As always, you don’t need to do anything to get the new release, auto-update should take care of that. This release has only two new user-level features, but a massive amount of improvements under the hood. We also fixed a lot of bugs, so hopefully it will provide a smoother experience. Here are the release highlights: We added a documentation browser. This provides a more permanent home for documentation in ...
